key_points: Economics studies how individuals, businesses, and governments allocate resources.
Microeconomics focuses on individual decisions (e.g., supply and demand), while macroeconomics deals with larger economic factors like GDP and inflation.
As price decreases, the quantity demanded increases; as price increases, the quantity supplied increases.
The cost of choosing one alternative over another; example: studying instead of working part-time.
Types include capitalism (market-driven), socialism (government-regulated), and mixed economies (combination).
Measures the total value of goods and services produced within a country.
Increase in prices over time, affecting purchasing power; example: rising food costs.
Percentage of jobless individuals actively seeking work; affects economic stability.
Includes regulating markets, setting fiscal policies (taxation, spending), and monetary policies (interest rates, money supply).
